overview: This subject will explore the scientific basis of disease.  Students will be introduced to factors affecting the initiation, progression and resolution of human disease through the study of:
Infection, immunity and immune mediated disease

Through lectures and tutorials students will understand that, as first described by Rudolf Virchow in 1958, ‘injury to the smallest living unit of the body, the cell, is the basis of all disease’, and appreciate how injury can lead to the development of diseases such as cancer and diabetes or cause a heart attack.
intended learning outcomes: Describe the factors affecting the initiation, progression and resolution of human disease
Apply the appropriate scientific terminology to the discussion of disease
Explain the relationship between normal and abnormal cell structure and function and its contribution to the development of disease

necessary pre-requisite: BIOL10005	Genetics and The Evolution of Life
additional pre-requisite: Students must complete one of these subject sets (A, B, C or D):
BIOL10004	 Biology of Cells and Organisms
BIOL10004	 Biology of Cells and Organisms
BIOL10005	Genetics and The Evolution of Life

non-allowed subjects: This subject is not available to students admitted to Bachelor of Biomedicine.
